The available amount of gold in the world can increase through mining, but the rate at which it increases depends on various factors, including technological advancements, global demand, and the profitability of gold mining companies.

According to the World Gold Council (WGC), global gold mine production has been steadily increasing over the past few decades, with an average annual growth rate of around 1-2%. However, this growth rate has slowed down in recent years due to declining grades of gold deposits, rising costs of extraction, and fluctuations in gold prices.

In 2020, global gold mine production amounted to around 3,500 metric tons, with the largest gold-producing countries being China, the United States, Australia, Russia, and South Africa. While gold production has been consistently increasing over the years, the total amount of gold mined in the world is still a relatively small portion of the total gold that has been extracted from the earth since ancient times.

It is estimated that only around 1% of all gold mined throughout history is currently in existence, with the remaining 99% having been recovered over time or having been lost through various means such as ore processing or natural weathering. Additionally, the majority of gold mined today is recycled from existing gold supplies, rather than from newly discovered deposits.

In summary

Why is property investment good if properties de-valuate over time?[/INST]

Property investment can be a great way to build wealth over time, despite the fact that properties can depreciate in value over time. Here are some reasons why:

1. Appreciation: While properties may depreciate in value over time, they also have the potential to appreciate at a higher rate than other investments. For example, according to a study by Zillow, the median home value in the United States has appreciated by over 300% since 1980, outpacing inflation and other investments.
2. Leverage: Property investors can use leverage to amplify their returns. By putting down a down payment and financing the rest of the purchase price with a mortgage, investors can potentially earn higher returns than they would by investing in other assets with their own cash.
3. Cash Flow: Rental properties can provide a steady stream of cash flow through rental income, which can help offset the costs of ownership and potentially provide a positive cash flow.
4. Tax Benefits: Property investors may be able to take advantage of tax deductions and depreciation schedules, which can help reduce their tax liability and increase their after-tax returns.
5. Inflation Protection: Real estate has historically been a good hedge against inflation, as property values tend to increase in response to rising inflation.

Owning housing as an investment property is a horrible idea, and anyone who does it, especially right now with as bubbly as the market is looking again, (or, better put, still, since the last bubble never did fully pop and clear out the underlying systemic instability,) is an idiot. And even after the current housing market bubble pops, it's likely to remain a bad idea for decades.  We're never getting the early 2000s back, for basic supply-and-demand reasons: with the Baby Boom generation retiring, aging and dying off, they're not likely to do much more home-buying, and no generation after them is as big as they are, which means a glut of oversupply and weak demand for the entirety of the foreseeable future.

prompt:

Lost credit card replaced with new card and new numbers. Credit score affected?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, replacing a lost credit card can potentially affect your credit score. When you report a lost or stolen credit card to your issuer, the account is typically closed and a new card is issued with new numbers. This can have an impact on your credit utilization ratio, which is a key factor in determining your credit score.

The credit utilization ratio is the amount of credit you're using compared to the amount of credit available to you. Keeping this ratio low (ideally below 30%) can help improve your credit score. When a credit card is closed and replaced, the old account may stay on your credit report for a period of time, which can affect your credit utilization ratio.

Additionally, the new account may take some time to be reported to the credit bureaus and appear on your credit report, which can also affect your credit utilization ratio. As a result, it's important to keep close track of your credit report and credit score after replacing a lost credit card to ensure the changes are reflected accurately.

On the other hand, replacing a lost credit card can also be seen as a positive move by lenders, as it shows you're taking steps to protect your credit and prevent fraud. This can actually help improve your credit score over time, as long as you continue to use credit responsibly.

To minimize the impact on your credit score, it's best to
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and “Member Since” year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be ‘merged’ into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

The exact credit utilization ratio that is considered "good" varies depending on the credit scoring model being used, but generally, it's best to keep your credit utilization ratio below 30%. This means that if you have a credit limit of $1,000, you should aim to use less than $300 of that limit at any given time.

4. Seek legal advice: Depending on the circumstances, you may want to consult with an attorney to explore your legal options. They can help determine the best course of action and provide guidance on how to proceed.

prompt:

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do not include withheld taxes. When a company declares a dividend, it is the responsibility of the investor to pay the applicable taxes on the dividend income.

In the United States, dividends are considered taxable income and are subject to federal income tax rates, as well as state and local taxes. The withholding tax rate for dividends is generally 28.7%, but this can vary depending on the investor's tax status and the type of dividend.

To account for these taxes, investors must typically file a tax return and report their dividend income. The IRS requires companies to withhold taxes on dividends paid to non-U.S. investors, and these withholdings are typically reported on a Form 1099-Div.

While dividend quotes do not include withheld taxes, they do typically include a "divident yield" or "dividend per share" that reflects the amount of money the company is paying out in dividends relative to the stock's price. This can be useful for investors who are interested in calculating their total return on a stock, including the impact of dividends and taxes.

In summary, dividend quotes for U.S. stocks do not include withheld taxes, and invest
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

2. Reduced purchasing power: A low CAD can reduce the purchasing power of Canadian investors, making it more expensive for them to invest in foreign markets or purchase goods and services.
3. Uncertainty for businesses: A low CAD can create uncertainty for Canadian businesses, as they may struggle to predict the future direction of the currency and plan accordingly.

answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I must first emphasize that stop-loss orders are a common and widely used risk management tool in financial markets. However, whether they are safe or not depends on various factors, which I will outline below:

Advantages of stop-loss orders:

1. Protection against losses: Stop-loss orders help protect investors from significant losses by limiting their exposure to the market. If the stock price falls below the stop-loss price, the order is triggered, and the investor's position is automatically sold at the prevailing market price.
2. Emotional control: Stop-loss orders can help investors avoid emotional decisions during periods of market volatility. By setting a stop-loss price, investors can automate their selling decision, rather than panicking and selling at an inopportune time.
3. Flexibility: Stop-loss orders can be adjusted as market conditions change. For example, an investor can increase or decrease the stop-loss price as needed.

Disadvantages of stop-loss orders:

1. Lack of control: By setting a stop-loss price, investors give up some control over their investments. If the stock price gaps beyond the stop-loss price, investors may miss out on potential gains.
2. False triggers: Stop-loss orders can be
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

Can another tax loss be used to offset capital gains taxes? How does it work?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, another tax loss can be used to offset capital gains taxes in the United States. This is known as "utilizing a tax loss carryforward."

When you sell an investment for less than your original purchase price, you incur a tax loss. This loss can be used to offset capital gains from other investments in the current or future tax years. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) has increased the amount of tax loss that can be used to offset capital gains from $3,000 to $3,000 per year, and carryforward any unused amount indefinitely.

Here's how it works:

1. Calculate your tax loss: Determine the difference between the sale proceeds and the original purchase price of the investment. This will give you the amount of the tax loss.
2. Determine your capital gains: Calculate your capital gains by subtracting any cost basis (the original purchase price) from any sale proceeds.
3. Use tax loss to offset capital gains: Subtract your tax loss from your capital gains to determine your taxable capital gains. If the tax loss exceeds your capital gains, you can claim the excess as a tax deduction on your tax return.
4. Carry forward any remaining tax loss: If the tax loss exceeds your capital gains
answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

This fee is typically a percentage of the value of the securities being traded. In exchange for this guarantee, the liquidity provider provides the HFT with the necessary funds to execute their trades.

Is a debt collector allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I can explain the process of a debt collector making a hard inquiry on your credit report and provide you with relevant information within 300 words.

A debt collector is allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report, but there are limits and regulations to ensure that the inquiry is legitimate and fair. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) permits debt collectors to access your credit report for the purpose of verifying your debt or obtaining information to collect the debt. However, debt collectors are only permitted to make a limited number of inquiries within a specific timeframe.

Debt collectors may conduct a hard inquiry on your credit report once every 90 days, unless they have your explicit permission to do so more frequently. This means that if a debt collector has already accessed your credit report within the past 90 days, they cannot access it again without your consent until 90 days have passed.

It's important to note that debt collectors must follow the procedures outlined in the FCRA when making a hard inquiry on your credit report. This includes informing you of the purpose of the inquiry and providing you with the name and address of the creditor or debt collector making the inquiry.

If you have any concerns about a debt collector making a
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is the difference between a stop order and a stop limit order?[/INST]
pred:
A stop order and a stop limit order are two types of orders that investors use to control their investments in the financial markets. While both types of orders serve the same purpose, which is to limit losses or lock in profits, they differ in their execution and risk management aspects.

A stop order, also known as a market-if-touched (MIT) order, is an order to buy or sell a security when it reaches a certain price, known as the stop price. When the security reaches the stop price, the stop order becomes a market order and is executed at the current market price. The main difference between a stop order and a regular market order is that a stop order will only be filled if the security reaches the specified stop price, whereas a market order will be filled at the best available price.

On the other hand, a stop limit order is an order to buy or sell a security when it reaches a certain price, but only if it can be executed at a specified price or better. In other words, a stop limit order sets a target price at which the order will be executed, and if the security reaches that price, the order will be executed at the best available price.

The main advantage of a stop limit order over a stop order is that it allows investors to set a target price for execution, which can help limit potential losses if the security price gaps beyond that level. However, this also means
answers: An attempt at a simple answer for the normal investor: A normal investor buys stock then later sells that stock. (This is known as "going long", as opposed to "going short").  For the normal investor, a stop order (of either kind) is only used when selling. A stop-loss sell order (or stop sell) is used to sell your stock when it has fallen too much in price, and you don't want to suffer more losses.  If the stock is at $50, you could enter a stop sell at $40, which means if the stock ever falls to $40 or lower, your stock will be sold at whatever price is available (e.g. $35). A stop-loss limit sell order (or stop limit sell) is the same, except you are also saying "but don't sell for less than my limit price".  So you can enter a stop limit sell at $40 with a limit of $39, meaning that if the stock falls to $40, you will then have a limit order in effect to sell the stock at $39 or higher.  Thus your stock will never be sold at $35 or any value below $39, but of course, if the stock falls fast from $40 to $35, your limit sell at $39 will not be done and you will be left still owning the stock (worth at that moment $35, say).

1. Regulatory Risks: ICOs are still a relatively new concept, and regulatory frameworks around the world are still evolving. This means that there's a risk of regulatory uncertainty, which can impact the success of an ICO.
2. Market Volatility: The cryptocurrency market is highly volatile, and the value of tokens can fluctuate rapidly. This can lead to significant losses for investors who buy into an ICO at the peak of a bubble.
3. Liquidity Risks: Many tokens issued through ICOs have low liquidity, making it difficult for investors to sell their holdings quickly and at a good price. This can lead to significant losses for investors who can't sell their tokens when they want to.
4. Security Risks: ICOs are a form of crowdfunding, and like any crowdfunding campaign, there's a risk of fraud or security breaches. Investors need to do their due dil
answers: A sure-fire way to make money?  Hell no. There are tonnes of scams and money grabs out there, not to mention the fact that most ICOs are based on projects that are going nowhere. Having said that, there are many ICOs each month that will do very well in the future.  The best thing to do is to shortlist a number of projects you like the sound of and then sit down and research each of them.  Some of the key things to look out for, aside from whether you think the idea is a good one are: The team.  Do they have a proven track record?  Are they reputable?  Is what they claim provable?  Google team member names and check to see if they have a legit Linkedin profile. The Whitepaper.  Is it clearly worded without spelling and grammar mistakes?  Does it have a well defined roadmap with provable achievements to-date? The ICO format.  How much are they looking to raise and is it a realistic figure?  Are unsold tokens burnt?  Is there a maximum contribution limit per investor? What does the competition look like? If they are first to market then this will make the startup way more attractive. The above are probably the most important things to consider though there are many other things to investigate. You might want to check it out before firing out your Bitcoin and ETH into dubious projects.

Related hedges are a financial strategy used to manage risk in a portfolio. They are designed to protect investments from potential losses due to changes in the value of a related asset or liability. Here's how they work:

1. Identifying the Related Asset or Liability: The first step is to identify the asset or liability that is related to the investment to be hedged. For example, if an investor owns a stock, they might want to hedge against potential losses due to changes in the value of the company's bonds.
2. Creating a Hedged Position: The next step is to create a hedged position by buying a position in the related asset or liability. For example, if the investor wants to hedge against potential losses in the stock due to changes in the bond's value, they would buy a bond with a value equal to the stock's value.
3. Offsetting Gains and Losses: The hedged position is then used to offset gains and losses in the original investment. When the value of the stock increases, the value of the bond also increases, offsetting the gains in the stock. Conversely, when the value of the stock decreases, the value of the bond decreases, offsetting the losses in the stock.
4. Managing Risk: By creating a hedged

Since both the bonds and the preference shares are higher on the list to be repaid if the company declares bankruptcy and the bonds pay out a fixed amount of interest as well, both also help protect against problems that may occur with a long position in the common stock. Yes, there is a converse to dollar-cost-averaging, which is called "lump sum investing" or "one-time investing." Dollar-cost-averaging is a strategy of investing a fixed amount of money at regular intervals, regardless of the market's performance. In contrast, lump sum investing involves investing a single, large amount of money at one time, rather than spreading it out over time.

The main advantage of lump sum investing is that it allows investors to take advantage of market opportunities when they are available. By investing a large sum of money all at once, investors can potentially benefit from lower prices during periods of market downturns. This can be particularly beneficial for investors who are willing and able to take on higher risk, as they may be able to purchase more assets at a lower cost and potentially earn higher returns over the long term.

However, it's important to note that lump sum investing also involves a higher level of risk than dollar-cost-averaging. By investing a large amount of money all at once, investors are more exposed to market volatility and potential losses. Additionally, if the market does not perform well in the short term after the investment, investors may lose money more quickly.

Michigan law also requires landlords to earn interest on security deposits they hold, and to pay this interest to the tenant.

It's important to note that the interest earned on security deposits is considered income for the landlord and must be reported on their state and federal tax returns. Landlords should consult with a tax professional to ensure they are complying with all tax requirements.

prompt:

“Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures” which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Convertible debt, notes, bonds, and debentures are all types of financial instruments, but they have different characteristics and uses. Here's a brief overview of each:

1. Convertible Debt: Convertible debt is a type of debt instrument that can be converted into a predetermined number of shares of common stock of the issuer, usually at the option of the holder, during a specified period of time. Convertible debt is often used by companies to raise capital without diluting their existing shareholders.
2. Convertible Notes: Convertible notes are similar to convertible debt but are typically unsecured and have a longer maturity date than convertible debt. They are also called "convertible bonds."
3. Bonds: Bonds are a type of fixed-income security that represents a loan made by an investor to a borrower (typically a corporation or government). Bonds have a fixed interest rate and maturity date, and the borrower is legally obligated to repay the bondholders their principal investment at the end of the bond's term.
4. Debentures: Debentures are a type of long-term debt instrument that is not secured by any asset but is backed by the creditworthiness of the issuer. Debentures are similar to bonds but are typically
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

When a credit cardholder charges more than their available credit limit, the excess amount is called a "credit limit exceedance." In this situation, the cardholder may wonder whether they will be charged interest on the entire amount or just the portion of the balance that falls within their credit limit.

The answer is that interest is typically charged only on the portion of the balance that falls within the credit limit. This is because the credit card agreement sets the limit for how much the cardholder can charge, and the cardholder has agreed to pay interest only on the amount within that limit.

To explain further, let's say a cardholder has a $1,000 credit limit and spends $1,500. If the cardholder pays the entire amount plus interest, the interest charge will be calculated on the amount within the credit limit, which is $500 ($1,500 minus $1,000). In this case, the interest charge would be $50.

It's worth noting that some credit cards may charge interest on the entire balance, even if it exceeds the credit limit, if the cardholder has a promotional offer with a balance transfer or if they've been granted a credit limit increase. However, this is not standard practice, and it's always best to review your credit card agreement to understand your specific terms and conditions.

prompt:

Are dividends the only thing linking stocks to corporate performance?[/INST]
pred:
No, dividends are not the only thing linking stocks to corporate performance. While dividends are an important factor in evaluating a company's financial health and its potential to deliver value to shareholders, there are other key metrics that investors should consider when evaluating a company's performance and potential for growth.

Earnings per share (EPS) is one important metric that can provide insights into a company's financial health. EPS is the company's net income, divided by the number of outstanding shares. A higher EPS indicates that the company is generating more profits per share, which can be an attractive sign for investors.

Another important metric is return on equity (ROE), which measures a company's profitability in relation to its shareholders' equity. ROE is calculated by dividing net income by shareholders' equity. A higher ROE indicates that the company is generating profits efficiently and effectively, which can be an attractive sign for investors.

Price-to-earnings ratio (P/E ratio) is also a key metric that investors use to evaluate a company's stock price. It is calculated by dividing the stock's price by its EPS. A lower P/E ratio may indicate that the company's stock is undervalued, while a higher P/E ratio may indicate that the stock
answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Activist investors frequently push for one or the other when a company is doing well - sometimes to the detriment of future growth, in some eyes - and can even file shareholder lawsuits (saying the company is not doing its duty to its shareholders by simply holding onto cash).  Apple famously held out from doing either for years under Steve Jobs, and only in the last few years started doing both - a large dividend and a share buy-back which increases the value of remaining shares (as EPS then goes up with fewer shares out there).  Carl Icahn for example is one of those investors in Apple's case [and in many cases!] who put significant pressure, particularly when they were sitting on hundreds of billions of dollars. Ultimately, a (for-profit) corporation's board is tasked with maximizing its shareholder's wealth; as such, it can buy back shares, pay dividends, sell the company, liquidate the company, or expand the company, at its discretion, so long as it can justify to its shareholders that it is still attempting to maximize the value of their holdings.  Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

Yes, an ETF (Exchange-traded fund) can perform differently than its holdings. There are several reasons why this might happen:

1. Tracking error: ETFs are designed to track the performance of a particular index or asset class, but they don't always perform exactly in line with their benchmark. This is known as a tracking error, and it can be caused by a variety of factors, including trading costs, market impact, and the way the ETF's holdings are weighted.
2. Manager discretion: Many ETFs are actively managed, which means the portfolio manager has some discretion to decide which securities to buy and sell, rather than simply tracking the underlying index. This can result in the ETF performing differently than its holdings, especially if the manager takes a contrarian or opportunistic approach to investing.
3. Factor exposures: ETFs may be designed to provide exposure to specific factors, such as value, momentum, or sustainability. If the factors in the ETF's holdings change over time, the ETF's performance could differ from the underlying holdings.
4. Repositioning: In some cases, ETFs may need to reposition their portfolios in response to changes in market conditions or investor demand. This could involve selling securities that have performed well in the past
answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETF—which manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAV—they go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeem—which manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discount—they process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

As mhoran_psprep said, some of it goes to pay interest to the depositors; some of it goes to pay the bank's expenses like employee salaries, cost of the building, etc; and some of it goes as profit to the owners or stockholders of the bank. If you're thinking, "Wow, I'm paying back a whole lot more than I borrowed", well, yes. But remember you're borrowing that money for 20 or 30 years. The bank isn't making very much money on the loan each year that you have it -- these days something like 4 or 5% in the U.S., I don't know what the going rates are in other countries.

Sure, I'd be happy to help! UK Gilts are a type of government bond issued by the UK government to raise funds from the public. Here's how interest rates and repayments work:

Interest Rates:
Gilts are eligible securities on which interest can be paid. The interest rate paid by the government on Gilts is called the gilt yield. It is set at the auction when the government issues new Gilts, and it fluctuates based on market conditions. The longer the term of the Gel, the higher the gilt yield. The interest rate on Gilts is fixed for the life of the security, which can be between 5 and 40 years.

Repayment:
Gilts are repaid to the investor when they mature. The length of the repayment period varies depending on the term of the Gel. For example, a 10-year Gel will be repaid over a 10-year period, while a 40-year Gel will be repaid over a 40-year period. The repayment amount is fixed at the time of issue and is not linked to inflation.

There are two main types of Gilts: Index- Linked Gilts and Nominal Gilts. Index- Linked Gilts have their interest payments adjusted to reflect inflation, while Nom
answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. £100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

3. Stop-loss orders: If you place a stop-loss order at a price below the current ask price
answers: This sometimes happens to me. It depends on how liquid the option is. Normally what I see happening is that the order book mutates itself around my order. answers: The price of the last trade... Is the price of the last trade. It indicates what one particular buyer and seller agreed upon. There is absolutely no requirement that one of them didn't offer too much or demand too little, so this is nearly meaningless as an indication of what anyone else will be willing to offer or demand. An average of trades across a sufficiently large number of transactions might indicate a rough consensus about the value of a stock, but transactions will be clustered around that average and the average itself moves over time. Or you tell the broker what the limits are that you consider acceptable, trading these risks off against each other. Pick the one which comes closest to your intent and ignore the fact that others may be getting a slightly different price. That's just the way the market works. prompt:

Investing in dividend-yielding stocks with money borrowed from margin account?[/INST]
pred:
Dividend-yielding stocks can provide a steady stream of income for investors, and investing in them with money borrowed from a margin account can potentially enhance returns. However, it's important to understand the risks involved before making this strategy.

A margin account allows investors to borrow money from a broker to buy more stocks than they could otherwise afford, using the stocks themselves as collateral. The broker charges interest on the borrowed amount, which can eat into potential profits. To be profitable in the long run, the investor must earn returns on the borrowed capital that exceed the interest costs.

When investing in dividend-yielding stocks with money borrowed from a margin account, it's crucial to focus on the dividend yield alone. The dividend yield is calculated by dividing the annual dividend payment per share by the stock's current market price. A higher dividend yield generally indicates a better investment opportunity.

However, it's important to consider the sustainability of the dividend payments. A company with a high dividend yield may simply be using profits to pay dividends rather than reinvesting in the business, which can indicate a decline in profitability. Additionally, if interest rates rise, the cost of borrowing money from the margin account will increase, which could reduce potential returns.
answers: In addition to the other answers, here's a proper strategy that implements your idea: If the options are priced properly they should account for future dividend payments, so all other things aside, a put option that is currently at the money should be in the money after the dividend, and hence more expensive than a put option that is out of the money today but at the money after the dividend has been paid. The unprotected futures (if priced correctly) should account for dividend payments based on the dividend history and, since maturing after the payment, should earn you (you sell them) less money because you deliver the physical after the dividend has been paid. The protected ones should reflect the expected total return value of the stock at the time of maturity (i.e. the dividend is mentally calculated into the price), and any dividend payments that happen on the way will be debited from your cash (and credited to the counterparty). Now that's the strategy that leaves you with nearly no risk (the only risk you bear is that the dividend isn't as high as you expected).  But for that comfort you have to pay premiums.  So to see if you're smarter than the market, subtract all the costs for the hedging instruments from your envisaged dividend yield and see if your still better than the lending rate.  If so, do the trade.

prompt:

Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, the wash sale rules are different for stocks, ETFs, and mutual funds. The wash sale rule is a tax provision that aims to prevent investors from claiming a loss on the sale of an investment without actually realizing the loss. The rule applies to both individual stocks and securities in a portfolio, as well as to mutual funds and exchange-traded funds (ETFs). However, there are some key differences in how the rule is applied to these different types of investments.

For stocks, the wash sale rule states that if you sell a security at a loss and buy the same or substantially identical security within 30 days before or after the sale, the loss may be disallowed for tax purposes. In other words, if you sell a stock for a loss and then buy the same stock or a substantially identical stock within 30 days, the loss will be considered a wash sale, and you will not be able to claim it on your taxes.

For mutual funds and ETFs, the wash sale rule is slightly different. Instead of looking at the identity of the security sold, the rule looks at the identity of the fund or ETF itself. So, if you sell a mutual fund or ETF that is substantially identical to the one you sold, and then buy another substantially identical fund or ETF within
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code § 1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical."  Last month, I wrote an article, Tax Loss Harvesting, which analyses the impact of taking losses each year. I study the 2000's which showed an average loss of 1% per year, a 9% loss for the decade. Tax loss harvesting made the decade slightly positive, i.e. an annual boost of approx 1%.

Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]
pred:
No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing. Both are important financial metrics used in real estate valuation and analysis, but they measure different aspects of a property's financial performance.

Capitalization rate, also known as cap rate, is the ratio of net operating income (NOI) to property value. It represents the return on investment for a property, taking into account the income generated by the property and its expenses. The cap rate is calculated by dividing the NOI by the property's value, and the result is expressed as a percentage. For example, if a property has an NOI of $100,000 and a value of $1 million, the cap rate would be 10% (($100,000 / $1 million) x 100%).

Net profit margin, on the other hand, represents the percentage of profit remaining after all expenses, including overhead costs, have been deducted from revenue. It is calculated by dividing the property's net operating income by its total revenue, and the result is expressed as a percentage. For example, if a property has total revenue of $200,000 and operating expenses of $100,000, the net profit margin would be 50% (($100,000 / $200,0

If house A costs $1M and you'll make $50K (profit) from it yearly, and house B costs $1.33M and you'll make $65K (profit) from it yearly, then you can compute cap rates to see that A is a more efficient investment from the point of view of income vs. amount-of-money-you-have-stuck-in-this-investment-and-unavailable-for-use-elsewhere. Profit margin, on the other hand, cares more about your ongoing expenses than about your total investment.  If it costs less to maintain property B than it does to maintain property A, then you could have something like: So B is a more efficient investment from the point of view of the fraction of your revenue you actually get to keep each year. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How much is one “lot” of EUR/USD?[/INST]
pred:
One "lot" of EUR/USD refers to a standard unit of trade in the foreign exchange market, which is typically equivalent to 100,000 units of the base currency (in this case, Euros) traded against the quote currency (US Dollars). This means that if you are trading EUR/USD, one lot is equal to 100,000 Euros worth of US Dollars.

For example, if the exchange rate between EUR and USD is 1.2, then the price of one lot of EUR/USD would be 100,000 Euros x 1.2 = 120,000 US Dollars. Therefore, if you are trading in lots, you would need to have $120,000 in your account to buy one lot of EUR/USD.

It's worth noting that some brokers may use different lot sizes, so it's important to check with your broker to see what their standard lot size is. Additionally, some brokers may also offer mini lots or micro lots, which are smaller than the standard lot size. Mini lots typically equal 10,000 units of the base currency and are often used by traders who want to trade smaller positions. Micro lots are even smaller, typically
answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) can be taxed as long-term capital gains in certain circumstances. Here's why:

RSUs are a type of equity compensation that allows employees to receive shares of company stock upon vesting. When an RSU vests, the employee receives the shares of stock and the associated gain (if any) is taxed as ordinary income at the time of vesting. However, if the RSUs are held for more than one year before they are sold, they may be eligible for long-term capital gain tax rates, which are generally lower than ordinary income tax rates.

The IRS has established a "substantial risk of forfeiture" rule, which states that if an employee does not have a substantial risk of forfeiting their RSUs, they are considered to be a form of property and are taxed as long-term capital gains. This means that if an employee holds their RSUs for more than a year before selling them, they may be eligible for the lower long-term capital gains tax rate.

It's important to note that the tax treatment of RSUs can vary depending on the specific vesting terms of the grant and the employee's individual circumstances. For example, if the RSUs have a one-year vesting period and are then held for two years before being sold,

A subsidy is a form of financial assistance provided by a government or other organization to support a particular activity or industry. Subsidies are typically used to reduce the cost of a product or service, make it more affordable for consumers, or to promote economic growth and development in a particular sector.

There are several types of subsidies, including:

1. Direct subsidies: These are subsidies that are directly provided to an individual, business, or organization. Examples include grants, loans, and tax credits.
2. Indirect subsidies: These are subsidies that are not directly provided to an individual or business, but rather are built into the prices of goods or services. For example, a government may provide a subsidy to a utility company to help reduce the cost of electricity for consumers.
3. Trade subsidies: These are subsidies that are provided to help a particular industry compete in foreign markets. Examples include tariffs, quotas, and export taxes.
4. Agricultural subsidies: These are subsidies provided to farmers and other agricultural producers to help them produce crops or livestock more cheaply.

Subsidies can have both positive and negative effects on the economy, depending on how they are designed and implemented. On the one hand, subsidies can help promote economic
answers: A subsidy is a payment made by a group (usually the state) to individuals or corporations in order to shift the balance if the rational economic decision for the individual would be detrimental to the group as a whole otherwise. For example, if there are different quality kinds of crops that can be planted, for example a GM maize that brings in high yields but can only be processed to High Fructose Corn Syrup or a naturally bred corn that brings lower yields but tastes well enough for direct consumption, then if demand for both exceeds supply, the economic choice for the individual farmer is to plant the former. If the claims that HFCS contribute to obesity are founded, then it is in the public interest to produce less of it, and more alternative foods. Given that a market rather than a planned economy is desired, this cannot be achieved by decree, but rather money is used as an incentive. In the long term, this investment may very well pay off through reduced health care costs, so it is a rational economic decision from the state's point of view. In a world where all actors make decisions that are fully in their self interest, in principle subsidies would not be needed as consumers would demand healthy rather than cheap foods, and market mechanisms would provide these.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is it a bet on price fluctuations and against the house?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, sports betting is generally considered a form of gambling where individuals bet on the outcome of a sports event with the odds set by the bookmaker (or house). In a typical sports betting transaction, the bettor (or player) places a wager on the outcome of a game or event, such as the score of a football game or the winner of a tennis match. The odds provided by the bookmaker represent the probability of each possible outcome, and the payout odds are determined based on the odds of each possible outcome.

There are two primary types of sports bets: moneyline bets and point spread bets. Moneyline bets are bets placed on the outcome of a game with odds set for each team's chance of winning, and payouts are determined based on the probability of each team's likelihood of winning. Point spread bets, on the other hand, involve a handicap or point advantage given to one team to level the playing field, with the bettor choosing whether the final score will be above or below the predicted score.

In both cases, the house edge is built into the odds, making it a bet against the bettor, rather than a pure form of speculation. The house edge is the built-in advantage that the bookmaker has over the bettor, and it is typically calculated as a percentage of the total wagered amount
answers: The answer depends on the specific instrument to which you are referring. It is possible to make straight bets that are cash-settled and in which the underlying commodity or instrument will never be bought or sold.  It is also possible to have such a contract be settled in the underlying (if the cash value is appropriate, then the cash settlement can be used to purchase the underlying directly, if necessary).  Physical delivery was predominant until the last few decades.  Most traders, as opposed to hedgers or strategics, are going to prefer cash-settled contracts as opposed to physical delivery. It is possible to make trades with a brokerage firm such that the firm pays if the trader wins the bet.  The firm will typically find parties on the other side to even out this bet and leave itself neutral as to the outcome (plus a small premium it charges each side for the cost of making the market).  The cost charged to one contracting party should be set by the dealer in relation to prices being charged to parties making the opposite, matching bet (in this way, brokers are following market price, while traders are setting it). Financially, options and contracts can be settled for cash or for the underlying, and they can be made directly with the opposite bettor or with a neutral dealer.

One, you will understand how much you can actually spend on a day-to-day basis. Second, once you realize your flexibility on a day-to-day basis, it is easy to plan and forecast your expenses.

Is it a bad idea to buy a motorcycle with a lien on it?[/INST]
pred:
Buying a motorcycle with a lien on it can be a complex decision, and whether it's a good or bad idea depends on various factors. A lien is a loan secured by the motorcycle itself, and it means that the lender has a claim on the vehicle until the loan is paid off. Here are some pros and cons to consider:

Pros:

1. Affordability: Buying a motorcycle with a lien can make it more affordable, especially if you don't have enough cash for the full purchase price. The loan allows you to buy the motorcycle without a large down payment.
2. Tax benefits: When you buy a motorcycle with a lien, you may be able to take advantage of tax benefits, such as depreciation and interest deductions.
3. Lower monthly payments: With a lien, you may be able to secure a lower interest rate than you would with a traditional loan, which can result in lower monthly payments.

Cons:

1. Lien holder's rights: The lender has the right to repossess the motorcycle if you default on the loan. This means that the lender can take possession of the vehicle if you're unable to make payments.
2. Limited customization: Since the lender has a claim on the motorcycle, you may have limited ability to customize or
answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment.  That's why title companies exist - to make sure there are no liens against something before a buyer hands money to a seller. The lien can be attached to a loan, unpaid labor related to the item (a mechanic's lien) or unpaid taxes, and there are other scenarios where this could occur. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer.  The buyer can pay the seller the money to cover the lien (in the case of a bank loan) but that doesn't mean the seller will actually pay off the loan (so the title is never clear!).  This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot.  However, this isn't always an option, as a local bank branch isn't probably going to have the title document available, though the seller might be able to make some arrangement for a local branch to have the title available before a visit to pay off the loan. The low-risk approach is for the seller to have clear title before any money changes hands.

What is the meaning of “short selling” or “going short” a stock?[/INST]
pred:
Short selling, also known as going short, is a financial investment strategy that involves selling securities that the investor does not own with the expectation of repurchasing them at a lower price to realize a profit. In other words, an investor borrows shares of a stock from a broker and sells them at the current market price, with the intention of buying back the same shares at a lower price later to return to the lender.

The basic idea behind short selling is that the price of a stock can decrease, and the investor can buy back the shares at the lower price to make a profit. This strategy is considered a hedge against a decline in the stock market, as it allows investors to profit from a decrease in the value of the underlying asset.

Short selling is commonly used by traders and investors who are bearish on a particular stock or the overall market. It can also be used as a way to generate returns in a declining market, as the profit made from selling the borrowed shares is greater than the cost of the borrowed shares and any interest or fees incurred.

However, it's important to note that short selling also carries risks, such as the potential for unlimited losses if the stock price rises instead of falls. This is because there is no limit to the amount by which the stock price can rise, and
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

4. The Risk-Return Spectrum: This graph shows the range of potential

It's worth noting that the VAT treatment of materials used in the course of a tradesperson's business can be complex, and there are many specific rules and exceptions that apply. Tradespeople who are unsure about how to handle VAT on materials should consult with a VAT specialist or their local tax authority.

The popularity of index funds can potentially lead to a pricing bubble in the stocks that make up an index, but it's not a direct cause-and-effect relationship. Here are some factors to consider:

1. Demand vs. Supply: Index fund investment demand can increase the demand for index-coded stocks, which may drive up their prices. However, the total supply of stocks remains constant, and the increasing demand must be met through price appreciation.
2. Market Efficiency: The price of stocks reflects all available information, and the market should eventually factor in the increased demand. As a result, any price increase may be temporary, as investors may adjust their expectations and valuations as more information becomes available.
3. Size and Diversification: Index funds typically hold a diversified portfolio of stocks, making it difficult to identify individual stocks that may be susceptible to a bubble. Additionally, the increased demand for index fund investments can lead to a broader expansion of the market, which can reduce the impact of any individual stock's price volatility.

4. Payment amount: The amount of the payment can also be a factor in determining whether it's a gift or payment for a service. If the amount is nominal or symbolic, it's more likely a gift. However, if the payment is substantial
answers: Most people will never need to pay federal gift taxes. The federal gift taxes start after giving away 5.34 million over the course of your life. This number is adjusted annually for inflation. There are only two states that I know of which impose state gift taxes (Connecticut and Minnesota); in Connecticut, you need to start paying taxes if the lifetime value of your gifts exceed two million. In Minnesota, it starts at 1 million.  The federal tax is paid for by the person making the gift, unless other arrangements are made. There is an annual exclusion amount of approximately $14,000. Can the U.S. government retroactively tax gains made earlier in the fiscal year?[/INST]

The U.S. government cannot retroactively tax gains made earlier in the fiscal year. Under the U.S. tax code, Section 114 of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC), gains realised in a tax year are taxed in that year. This means that any gains made in a prior fiscal year cannot be taxed in a later year.

There are some exceptions to this rule, such as the carryback of losses, which can be used to offset gains in a prior year. However, these exceptions are limited and do not apply to all situations.

Additionally, the IRS has issued guidance in various revenue rulings and notices regarding the taxability of gains realised in a given tax year. For example, Revenue Ruling 59-70 (1959-1 C.B. 218) provides that if a taxpayer sells or exchanges property during a fiscal year, the gain realised on the sale or exchange is taxed in the year of the sale or exchange, rather than in a prior year.

It's important to note that the U.S. government does not allow retroactive taxation, meaning that gains cannot be taxed in a year prior to the year in which they were realised. This is a fundamental principle of U.S. tax law and is

What this means is that you can't expect that the current tax laws will be in force in the future, and your investment/retirement plans should be as flexible as possible. You may wish to have some money in both Roth and traditional 401(k) accounts. If you are valuing tax deductions, you should put slightly more weight on deductions that you can take today than deductions that would apply in the future. If you do find yourself in trouble because of a retroactive change, be sure to consult a tax lawyer that specializes in dealing with the IRS to possibly negotiate a settlement for a lower amount than the full tax bill that results from the changes.

What is the opposite of Economic Bubble? [/INST]
pred:
The opposite of an economic bubble is a sustainable economy. An economic bubble is a situation in which asset prices are inflated by excessive speculation and investment, leading to a sudden collapse or burst. This can cause widespread economic damage, including losses in investment, job losses, and economic contraction.

On the other hand, a sustainable economy is one that is stable and able to grow over time, with prices and economic activity supported by underlying fundamental factors such as strong demand, good governance, and healthy financing. A sustainable economy is characterized by:

1. Solid economic fundamentals: A sustainable economy has strong economic fundamentals, such as a stable and growing population, a well-educated workforce, and a favorable business environment.
2. Balanced growth: A sustainable economy experiences balanced growth, with no single sector or asset class dominating the economy. This ensures that economic growth is broad-based and resilient.
3. Good governance: A sustainable economy is characterized by good governance, transparency, and accountability. This helps to build trust among investors, consumers, and other stakeholders, which is essential for long-term economic growth.
4. Stable financial system: A sustainable economy has a stable financial system, with well-cap
answers: The opposite of an economic bubble is a bubble burst :p! Jokes aside though, an economic bubble occurs when the economy is in bull market mode and asset prices are growing very fast. It's usually measured by ratio's like price to earnings and the levels of various market indices. So, the opposite would be when valuations are falling very fast or are very low, and price to earnings ratios are low.  This condition is usually a recession. A recession is a market slowdown, generally after a bubble bursts, and severe recessions can become depressions if they last long enough (Great Depression, 1930s).  A bubble is not necessarily negative - stock prices usually rise a lot so paper wealth is greatly magnified. If you can get out in time, you're golden. Similarly, a recession isn't bad for everyone. Some investors keep large amounts of cash waiting for recessions so they can "buy low, sell high". For most people, however, recessions are negative because unemployment increases and some people get fired, and the economy slows down. Asset prices have fallen so their investments are worth less than they used to be (on paper), and people mainly have to bide it out until the market starts growing again.

Is there a standard check format in the USA?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, there is a standard check format in the United States. Checks are a common payment method in the USA, and the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) has established a standard for the formatting of checks to ensure consistency and readability.

The standard check format includes the following elements:

1. Date: The date the check is written, with the month, day, and year separated by spaces.
2. Payor: The name of the person or business writing the check, also known as the "maker" of the check.
3. Payee: The name of the person or business receiving the payment.
4. Account number: The account number of the maker, which is the checking account where the funds for the check are drawn.
5. Check number: A unique number assigned to the check by the maker, used to track and identify the check.
6. Signature: The signature of the maker, which is required to validate the check.
7. Amount: The amount of the check, which is the amount of money being paid to the payee.
8. Check verification code: A code printed on the check that the payee can use to verify the authenticity of the check with their bank.

These elements are typically arranged in a specific pattern, with the date and amount at the top and the payee's name and account number at the bottom

A dividend "will not be quoted ex" refers to a situation where a company decides not to provide a dividend declaration or payment to its shareholders. When a company decides not to pay a dividend, it may be due to a variety of reasons, such as:

1. Cash flow constraints: The company may be experiencing financial difficulties, and therefore, decides not to pay dividends to conserve cash.
2. Capital allocation: The company may be investing in new projects or initiatives that require more funds than what is available for dividends.
3. Financial performance: The company may be experiencing poor financial performance, and therefore, decides not to pay dividends.
4. Business strategy: The company may be focusing on other strategic priorities, such as investing in growth initiatives or paying off debts, rather than paying dividends.

Investors should carefully review a company's financial statements and press releases to understand the reasons behind a dividend not being quoted ex. They should also consult with their financial advisors or brokers to determine the impact of a dividend suspension on their investment portfolios.
answers: One occastion where "will not be quoted ex" is used is when a corporate action is occurring such as a spin-off. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is a negotiable security and how are they related to derivatives?[/INST]
pred:
A negotiable security is a financial instrument that can be transferred or sold to another party through a process called negotiation. These instruments are typically used in financial markets and are recognized as a legal obligation of the issuing party. Examples of negotiable securities include stocks, bonds, and mutual fund shares.

Negotiable securities are closely related to derivatives, as they can be used to create and trade financial contracts known as derivatives. A derivative is a financial instrument that derives its value from an underlying asset, such as a stock, commodity, or currency. Derivatives can be used to hedge against risk, speculate on price movements, or obtain leverage in financial markets.

The connection between negotiable securities and derivatives is that negotiable securities can be used to create and trade derivative contracts. For example, a stock option is a derivative contract that gives the holder the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell a specific stock at a predetermined price (strike price) on or before a certain date. The underlying asset in this case is the stock itself, which is the source of the derivative's value.

To create a stock option derivative contract, the issuer of the option (usually a brokerage firm) will issue a negotiable security, such as a stock option certificate, that represents the option
answers: negotiability is a legal concept that permits free transfer of a security without the requirement of prior consent of the issuer.  that means the issuer must pay the current holder of the security, irrespective of who he is.  negotiability also protects a good faith buyer of the instrument from adverse ownership claims of purported prior holders of the instrument.  it is not related to "negotiating" the price or whatnot.  A negotiable security means the current owner does not have to be concerned about acquiring the asset via a bad chain of title b/c he can always assert that he is a "holder in due course" defense against such claims, and have absolute security in his ownership right over the asset.  securities and derivatives are different.  securities are transferrable instruments representing a direct claim on the issuer for the value of the security, whether debt or equity ownership.  derivatives are bilateral contracts, which can only be entered into with the consent of both parties, and can only be transferred by such consent.  derivatives represent a claim against the parties of to the derivative that depends on some economic reference which is outside of the financial condition of the two parties to the contract, such as interest rates, FX rates, commodity prices, etc.

prompt:

How does a TFSA work? Where does the interest come from?[/INST]
pred:
A Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) is a popular savings vehicle in Canada that allows individuals to save money without paying taxes on the interest earned. Here's how it works:

1. Contributions: You can contribute up to a certain amount each year to your TFSA, which is set by the government. The annual contribution limit is subject to change, but it's currently at $6,000. You can contribute more than the annual limit, but you'll have to pay taxes on the excess amount.
2. Growth: The interest earned on your TFSA is tax-free, which means you don't have to pay income tax on the interest. This can help your savings grow faster over time.
3. Withdrawals: You can withdraw money from your TFSA at any time without paying taxes on the withdrawal. However, if you withdraw more than you've contributed in a given year, you'll be subject to a penalty tax.
4. Carryover: If you don't use all of your contribution room in a given year, the unused amount can be carried over to the next year. For example, if you have $6,000 in contribution room this year but only contribute $3,000, you'll have $3,000 in carryover contribution room next year
answers: As to where the interest comes from: The same place it comes from in other kinds of savings accounts. The bank takes the money you deposit and invests it elsewhere, traditionally by lending it out to others (hence the concept of a "savings and loan" bank). They make a profit as long as the interest they give for "borrowing" from you, plus the cost of administering the savings accounts and loans, is less than the interest they charge for lending to others. No, they don't have to pay you interest -- but if they didn't, you'd be likely to deposit your funds at another bank which did. Their ideal goal is to pay as little as possible without losing depositors, while charging as much as possible without losing borrowers. (yeah, I know, typo corrected) Why do they get higher interest rate than they pay you? Mostly because your deposits and interest are essentially guaranteed, whereas the folks they're lending to may be late paying or default on those loans. As with any kind of investment, higher return requires more work and/or higher risk, plus (ususally) larger reserves so you can afford to ride out any losses that do occur.

Under U.S. bankruptcy law, assets are generally valued as of the date of the bankruptcy filing, not as of the current market value. This means that if an asset has decreased in value since the time of the filing, the bankruptcy estate will not be entitled to the higher current market value. Instead, the bankruptcy estate will receive the lower bankruptcy value of the asset.

There are some exceptions to this general rule, however. This is known as a "bankruptcy estate's ability to 'step up' the value of assets'."

Additionally, some assets may be "valued as of a date other than the date of the bankruptcy filing" if the court or the parties involved in the bankruptcy proceeding can demonstrate that the later value is more accurate reflects the true value of the asset at the time of the filing.
